docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a parent of a child with special health care needs, I applaud the new rules on health insurance decisions and appeals issued by the president (news article, Nov. 21). They are a step in the right direction, benefiting not only patients, but also doctors, therapists, hospitals and clinics.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Reader's Digest Association said it would market Pethealth Inc.'s accident and health insurance policies for dogs and cats in the United States and Canada. Financial terms of the three-year contract were not released. Pethealth, based in Oakville, Ontario, is seeking a license to begin writing policies in the United States, starting in the first half of next year, that will probably cost consumers $210 to $220 a year. Reader's Digest estimates that about 20 million of the 53 million Americans in its marketing database own dogs or cats.

headline.main: READER'S DIGEST TO MARKET INSURANCE ON PETS

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a registered dietitian I was extremely saddened reading ''Who Is Fat? It Depends on Culture'' (Nov. 7). How can health insurance companies keep denying reimbursement for nutrition services when the numbers show that money and pain can be saved by losing weight? Every day I receive phone calls from people who are in desperate need and unable to afford nutrition services.

docs.lead_paragraph: Trigon Healthcare has begun a $675 million takeover offer for the Cerulean Companies, forcing WellPoint Health Networks to raise its two-year-old bid for Cerulean to $680 million. The companies are health insurers. In July 1998, WellPoint agreed to pay $500 million in cash and stock for Cerulean, the Atlanta-based parent of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Georgia; its offer had been held up pending resolution of shareholder lawsuits against Cerulean. Trigon, based in Richmond, Va., submitted its unsolicited bid Sunday. The 1998 agreement gave WellPoint the right to match competing offers. Cerulean's board has not formally responded to WellPoint's revised bid, but it has told Wellpoint management that the bid seems no better than Trigon's.

headline.main: TRIGON HEALTHCARE JOINS BIDDING FOR CERULEAN

docs.lead_paragraph: The converted motor home that pulled up to the central courtyard of the South Bronx housing project shortly before 3 p.m. was shrink-wrapped in a rainbow-colored display featuring smiling children and upbeat slogans like ''Get on Board With Kids' Health Insurance.'' Earlier, fliers had been slipped under the doors of the 1,200 apartments, signs had been plastered throughout the Dr. Ramon Emeterio Betances Houses on East 146th Street in Mott Haven, and dozens of telephone calls went out as last-minute reminders of the deal being offered inside the motor home and at the housing complex's office and community center: low-cost or free health insurance for children.

headline.main: Child Health Insurance Drive Progresses, but at Halting Pace

docs.abstract: New York City Deputy Mayor Anthony P Coles is coordinating effort called Health Stat to accelerate enrollment of uninsured children in free or low-cost health insurance plans; Mayor Giuliani plans meeting with clergy, whom mayor will ask to promote campaign in congregations and neighborhoods; Children's Defense Fund praises New York City's efforts to insure children; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was 21 degrees on the morning of Dec. 28, 1999. Pierre Blain, 26, turned on Channel 4 to check the temperature, then put on two pairs of socks and thermal boots to help stave off the cold. He thought he had the flu, but he reported to his job at a Jersey City furniture warehouse anyway because he needed the $67 that he would make that day. That evening, as Mr. Blain walked to the bus stop to catch a bus home, he collapsed on the frigid sidewalk.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Month's Rent and a Bridge Out of Crisis

docs.abstract: Pierre Blain receives assistance toward rent and electricity bill from Catholic Charities, one of seven local charities that receives money from New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; Blain, double amputee, was in danger of eviction; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NOT much upsets the bucolic serenity of this community, where horses graze on large farms and residents enjoy a rustic refuge just out of reach of Westchester's suburban sprawl to the south. But earlier this month, that calm was ruffled when a group of residents learned that Michael R. Bloomberg, the news entrepreneur, is set to buy the historic Sunshine Farm and build a 20-horse barn where his teenage daughter, Georgina, could keep her large stable of horses.

headline.main: In Horse Country, a Fight Over Horses

docs.abstract: Article on community opposition to entrepreneur Michael R Bloomberg's bid to build 20-horse barn on farm owned by Joseph J Pinto in North Salem, NY; Bloomberg is set to buy historic Sunshine Farm and build barn where his teenage daughter, Georgina, can keep her large stable of horses; group of residents has complained that Bloomberg's plan could threaten environment, property values and neighbors' health, as well as bring permanent smell to residential neighborhood; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BY 7 p.m. on a recent chilly night, the Cerruti store on Madison Avenue had begun to fill with young socialites and wispy models. Rumors that the rapper Jay-Z and his entourage were expected at the cocktail party under way there had already sent a little thrill through the throng. But as far as the phalanx of publicists on duty was concerned, the most important guest was already there, busily sucking all the air out of the room. ''God, you are so adorable, you're just the kind of girl I love,'' said Patrick McMullan, as Consuelo Remmert, a former model who is now a Columbia student, passed through the velvet ropes and glided up to him with a kiss. In a single balletic movement, Mr. McMullan tucked a lock of his hair behind his ear and swung his camera up to snap the shutter twice. Ms. Remmert tossed her tawny ponytail and dragged a manicured hand along his DKNY jacket as she disappeared into the crowd.

headline.main: All Parties, All the Time: New York's Bloodshot Eye

docs.abstract: Article on party photographer Patrick McMullan; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The town board of Greenburgh voted unanimously to provide health benefits for the same-sex partners of municipal enployees, becoming the second town in Westchester to do so. ''Surprisingly, there was no controversy,'' said Supervisor Paul J. Feiner. ''We had one speak up in favor, and one against.'' The new benefits plan will cost the town about $5,000 annually for each person covered. Mr. Feiner said he expected very few of the town's 475 employees to take advantage of it. Westchester County adopted a benefit plan for same-sex couples in 1998, and Eastchester adopted a similar policy in September. Robert Worth

headline.main: IN BRIEF: Government; BENEFITS FOR SAME-SEX COUPLES

docs.lead_paragraph: WEIGHING in on a controversy that has been stuck in Congressional gridlock for years, President Clinton issued new rules last week that promise quicker decisions for patients in disputes with managed-care companies and the right to appeal when insurance claims are denied. The regulations, issued by the Labor Department after four years of pressure from consumer groups and resistance from insurers and employers, will apply to 130 million Americans, about half the population. The rest are covered by similar rules under Medicare and other government programs.

headline.main: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOHN ROTHER; Assessing New Rules for Managed Care
